image.altText: A man with glasses and a navy blue suit and tie stands behind a lecturn at a business conference

props.synopsis: In his first broadcast interview since ACCC allegations became public, Qantas chairman Richard Goyder maintains he has the confidence of the board and says major investors want him to stay.

title.children: 'We know we've let people down': Qantas chairman dodges calls to quit

image.altText: A man wearing boxing gloves and a T-shirt.

props.synopsis: Eight men are charged with murdering Jason De Ieso in Adelaide's northern suburbs in 2012, but the lawyer for the man accused of firing the fatal shot says his client wasn't even there.

title.children: Olympic hopeful did not shoot Jason De Ieso, lawyer tells jury

image.altText: An old stone building with a red dome

props.synopsis: An Adelaide judge says crimes such as indecent filming are becoming more prevalent as technology evolves, with a need to send a message to others that it will not be tolerated.

title.children: 'Very concerning trend': Judge jails rapist who filmed sexual crimes against unconscious ex

image.altText: A police officer lifts police tape to let a car pass.

props.synopsis: A man will face court today charged with murder over the fatal stabbing of another man, who died at the scene of the alleged attack in Adelaide's north last night.

title.children: Murder charge laid over fatal stabbing in Adelaide's north

image.altText: Lindsay May looking up at the camera holding a painted abalone shell

props.synopsis: As debate over the Voice continues around the country, locals in this remote South Australian community are focused on issues closer to home.

title.children: This town only has enough jobs for 15 per cent of locals. The community is working to change that

image.altText: Julie Bishop speaks to the media

props.synopsis: A 24-year-old man is remanded in custody, charged with attempted murder and assault. The ANU says it was not given relevant information before the violent incident.

title.children: 'I was so angry': ANU chancellor Julie Bishop says university was in the dark ahead of stabbings

image.altText: Four men sitting for a press conference, a bald man in the centre wearing a suit

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide Football Club chairman David Koch says his faith in coach Ken Hinkley is not shaken by an inglorious straight-sets finals exit.

title.children: Koch says Port Adelaide Power board still behind coach despite AFL finals exit

image.altText: Photo of a person holding up an Aboriginal flag. Behind it, out of foucs, is an even larger Aboriginal flag.

props.synopsis: More young and Indigenous Australians are enrolled to vote than ever before, as the Australian Electoral Commission prepares to begin early voting in remote communities next week.

title.children: More Indigenous Australians and young people registered to vote than ever before ahead of Voice referendum

image.altText: A heavily tattooed man sitting in a car, taking a selfie.

props.synopsis: Stanley Turvey had been a fugitive for hours when he crossed paths with an unwitting Melbourne man having a drink at a caravan park. As the investigation into his shooting death begins, here's a look at how the manhunt unfolded.

title.children: 'What are you doing mate?' Stranger reveals he shared a 'quiet beer' with man on the run

image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño is likely to bring a scorching summer. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: The silhouette of a power station is seen against the sky in the early evening, with thick smoke billowing from three towers.

props.synopsis: There are growing safety concerns at Yallourn Power Station in Victoria, one of Australia's biggest coal-fired power plants. Experts say that could be bad news heading into a long, hot summer.

title.children: Dark clouds gather over one of Australia's biggest coal plants as El Niño heats the land

image.altText: Anthony Albanese putting on a mask at a press conference.

props.synopsis: An inquiry into government response to the COVID-19 pandemic has been announced, but state and territory local lockdowns and border closures are likely to avoid scrutiny.

title.children: Lockdowns and border closures omitted in scope of inquiry into government COVID-19 pandemic response

image.altText: A night vision image of a pet cat carrying native prey in it's mouth.

props.synopsis: An ecologist warns pet owners to keep predatory animals secure, after a cat is spotted on the Yorke Peninsula in South Australia posing a threat to recently reintroduced brush-tailed bettongs.

title.children: Pet cat caught on camera carrying native prey in national park home to precious endangered bettong colony

image.altText: A tall tower under construction with sculptures in the foreground

props.synopsis: An established construction company working on Adelaide's major One Festival Tower project has been placed into liquidation.

title.children: About 100 workers lose their jobs after collapse of another Adelaide builder

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD

props.synopsis: The bosses of Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, NAB and ANZ descended on Canberra to defend shutting hundreds of regional bank branches in recent years. Here's how they justified their decisions after spending a day under the microscope.

title.children: It costs every Commonwealth Bank customer $40 to keep cash available — but the majority of them don't use it

image.altText: A man is led away from a home by police.

props.synopsis: A 68-year-old Melbourne man is expected to appear in the ACT Magistrates Court tomorrow charged with the 1999 murder of Irma Palasics after an extradition hearing in Victoria today.

title.children: Man charged with 1999 murder of Irma Palasics extradited from Melbourne to Canberra

image.altText: emergency services at a crash scene where two young boys died

props.synopsis: A second man is charged over an alleged street race in Monterey in Sydney's south, that resulted in the deaths of two young children, and a third being injured.

title.children: Second man charged over alleged Sydney street race that killed two young children

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

image.altText: Senior man wearing a shirt receives an injection in his arm.

props.synopsis: If it has been six months or longer since you last had a COVID-19 infection or a vaccine dose, you are eligible for a jab. Here's what you need to know before getting one.

title.children: A new COVID-19 virus has been detected onshore. So is it time to get a booster?

image.altText: Josh Frydenberg speaking at the Liberal election launch

props.synopsis: Former treasurer and deputy Liberal leader Josh Frydenberg, once touted as a future prime minister before losing his seat at the last election, will become Goldman Sachs Australia chairman, ruling out seeking a political comeback at the next election.

title.children: Frydenberg political comeback on hold, takes new Goldman Sachs job

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: LeBron James set out to revolutionise America’s broken school system. Then the results came in

image.altText: Old newspaper articles

props.synopsis: The deadline for the final report into unsolved deaths suspected of being LGBTIQ hate crimes in NSW has been extended after police delayed providing crucial documents.

title.children: NSW Police need 900 years to clear backlog of unsolved homicides, gay hate inquiry told

image.altText: The Elvis Water Crane has been sent to East Gippsland

props.synopsis: The head of Australia's largest firefighting service says the nation needs a national aerial firefighting fleet.

title.children: Firefighters call for aerial fleet as nation braces for 'difficult' fire season

image.altText: Ben Wyatt speaking on the Yes campaign.

props.synopsis: High-profile Aboriginal leaders voting Yes in next month's Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum have used a community forum in Perth to call on supporters to ramp up their campaign.

title.children: Yes vote a 'marginal seat campaign' in WA as high-profile Indigenous leaders plead for action

image.altText: A shot of an active coal-fired power station near a residential area in China.

props.synopsis: World leaders are told "the future is not fixed" and urged to "make up time lost to foot dragging" on reducing emissions, at the UN Climate Ambition Summit in New York.

title.children: 'Humanity has opened the gates of hell': Key world leaders missing at UN summit as emissions targets go unmet

image.altText: Danushka Gunathilaka outside court

props.synopsis: In a closing address, Crown Prosecutor Gabrielle Steedman says the alleged victim's sexual episode with cricketer Danushka Gunathilaka "turned out very differently to what she expected or wanted".

title.children: Cricketer Danushka Gunathilaka pursued woman 'relentlessly' before alleged sexual assault, court told

image.altText: An Indonesian woman crying with her hand at her face.

props.synopsis: In the latest series of cases involving blasphemy laws in Indonesia, a TikToker with more than than 2 million followers is found guilty and jailed for two years for saying an Islamic phrase before eating crispy pork skin.

title.children: Woman jailed for two years and fined $25,000 for eating pork on TikTok in Indonesia

image.altText: On left, Penny Wong sits signing a large book; on right a turtle swims by a reef in the ocean

props.synopsis: Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong says Australia is working to bring the United Nations treaty "into force as soon as possible".

title.children: Australia signs landmark agreement to give world's shared oceans a 'fighting chance'

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: A teenage boy and girl, dressed in colourful clothes, walk their bikes as they chat outside school.

props.synopsis: The British sex comedy has portrayed the teenage experience with nuance and humour. Here's everything you need to know before pressing play on the final season.

title.children: The final season of Sex Education has arrived. Here's everything you need to know before saying goodbye

image.altText: Screenshot of Bob Ross with the Walk in the Woods painting during the first episode of his TV series.

props.synopsis: The painting is on sale after spending almost four decades hanging in a TV station volunteer's home.

title.children: First painting from Bob Ross's TV series goes on sale for more than $15m

image.altText: A Cambodian woman holds a sign reading "Pay your workers".

props.synopsis: The women making clothes and shoes for some of the world's biggest brands have seen their wages drop and are spiralling into debt, even as fashion companies see revenues rise, according to a new report.

title.children: They make clothes for the biggest sporting brands in the world. But these women are spiralling in debt distress

image.altText: Sufjan Stevens performing at the 2018 Academy Awards ceremony.

props.synopsis: The alternative musician is facing a long recovery after being diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

title.children: 'I woke up one morning and couldn't walk': Sufjan Stevens diagnosed with rare autoimmune disease

image.altText: A composite image of Darcy Moore (left) and Erin Phillips.

props.synopsis: The five-year collective bargaining agreement covering male and female players features significant wage rises and a longer AFLW season.

title.children: AFL strikes $2.2 billion pay deal with players in historic joint collective bargaining agreement

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material
